texts.shortText: Emerges from a small holdfast growing out of the stipes of the Sea bamboo Ecklonia maxima, or alternatively attached to the shells of the Kelp limpet Cymbula compressa. Forms clumps of elongate, narrow, terminally-pointed fronds, each with a distinct midrib and often spiraled. The elongate main fronds bear a few side branches and the margins of both main and side branches are lined with a frill of tiny oval leaflets. Texture tough and not slippery; colour purple-red.
Clumps up to 500 mm long, blades about 10 mm wide.

Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Cape Agulhas.

Found only on the stipes of kelps, or growing on the shells of the kelp limpet, which is also restricted to living on Ecklonia. The algae find protection from grazing by growing on the limpet shell, but the limpet can then get ripped off the kelp stipe during storms due to the drag caused by large clumps of algae attached to it!

Traditionally used as a source of agar for jelly-making, but not commercially collected (as are several other Gelidium species).
The reproductive structures are borne on the marginal leaflets.

Easily distinguished both by form and habitat, although might be confused with the Flaccid kelp-weed Carpoblepharus flaccida, which is also elongate, branched and epiphytic on kelps, but that species has a much softer, fleshier texture and lacks midribs.

Anderson, RJ & Bolton, JJ (1985). Suitability of the agarophyte Suhria vittata (L.) J. Ag.(Rhodophyta: Gelidiaceae) for mariculture: geographical distribution, reproductive phenology and growth of sporelings in culture in relation to light and temperature. South African Journal of Marine Science, 3(1), 169-178.

Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 402).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 300 as G. verrucosa).
